{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3702959,"name":"Maya","username":"mapemaya","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mapemaya/{size}/267073_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-05T19:18:46.166Z","cooked":"

Hey,
This off-season my team is planning to use the CANRange on our robot.

I‚Äôve been trying to find the best way to connect it, and haven‚Äôt found anything on the topic.

Is there a recommended way to connect it that I‚Äôm just not aware of\haven‚Äôt found yet?

Any help is appreciatedüôè

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-08-05T19:18:46.166Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":132,"readers_count":131,"score":126.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504988,"topic_slug":"connecting-canrange","display_username":"Maya","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/connecting-canrange/504988/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3702964,"name":"Jeremiah Orme","username":"Jorme1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jorme1/{size}/267682_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-05T19:24:25.160Z","cooked":"

Here is the documentation: CANrange User‚Äôs Guide (PDF)

The sensor features four Weidm√ºller ports: two for power (positive and negative) and two for CAN (green and yellow). It comes with pre-soldered wires that split the CAN connection into two, allowing it to be easily inserted into an existing CAN bus.

Yeah but I mean like where to connect it, to VRM to MPM‚Ä¶ etc
I already went over the user‚Äôs guide

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-08-05T20:48:34.051Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":36.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504988,"topic_slug":"connecting-canrange","display_username":"Maya","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53604,"username":"Jorme1","name":"Jeremiah Orme","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jorme1/{size}/267682_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/connecting-canrange/504988/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703060,"name":"Jeremiah Orme","username":"Jorme1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jorme1/{size}/267682_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-05T21:01:04.836Z","cooked":"

Here‚Äôs how we powered ours:
We used the Kraken X60 motor, powered through the Talon FX PowerPole Adapter Board (WCP‚Äë1380), and pulled power for the sensor from this board. Alternatively, you can power the sensor from the VRM ‚Äî or any reliable 12 V source.

Yes, you can use a MPM (5A fuse is enough) or VRM(12V/500mA port)

You can wire it pretty much anywhere that has 12V. You can dedicate a PDP/PDH channel, use a VRM, etc.
